lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent: Welcome to the exciting world of fetching data in React! We'll learn how to fetch data from an external source using the popular fetch API.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use the built-in function fetch inside our components to get data from an API.

Don't worry about the specifics yet; we'll refine this code as we go!

Make sure to pick fetch, followed by "https://swapi.mimo.dev/api/people".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We chain .then to handle asynchronous operations, ensuring each step executes after the previous one.

In the passed callback function, we convert the response body into a JavaScript object or array, making it usable in your code.

Make sure to pick .then, followed by response, and finally response.json().

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Next, we log the parsed JSON data to the console.

This step allows us to inspect or use the data returned from the previous .then.

Make sure to pick fetch, followed by "https://swapi.mimo.dev/api/people".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we put the fetch function into a useEffect hook with an empty dependency array, it will load once the component renders.

Make sure to pick useEffect followed by useEffect and then ,, [].

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can save the loaded data in a state variable to keep track of it and later display it.

Initiate the state variable data with null and update it with the received and parsed data once available.

Make sure to pick useState followed by useState and then null, setData, data.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finally, we can map over the data in the return statement and render it.

Map over the data to display the name of each loaded character.

Make sure to pick data followed by .map and then person, person.name.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Initializing the state variable data with null is a common way to use conditional rendering to show a loading state.

Make sure to pick null followed by data and then ?, :.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code to load the data from the endpoint.

Make sure to type fetch.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which method retrieves data from the URL in the Fetch API?

fetchgetDataloadrequire

Make sure to pick fetch.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now let's use the Fetch API to automatically retrieve data when the component mounts using the useEffect hook.

Make sure to pick useEffect, followed by , []).

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
What statement is correct?

.then chaining ensures asynchronous operations are executed in order.then chaining executes all operations simultaneously.then chaining can only handle synchronous operations.then chaining automatically catches errors

.then chaining ensures asynchronous operations are executed in order.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Ensure the data is only visible once it has been loaded successfully using conditional rendering.

Make sure to pick data, followed by ?, and finally :.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to avoid chaining .then calls, we can handle asynchronous operations using async and await.

This method results in a more straightforward and linear structure for managing asynchronous operations.

Make sure to pick fetchData, followed by async (), and finally await.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
await just waits until the call is done and continues with the next line afterward.

After saving the data in response, we convert the response body into a JavaScript object or array, once the data is available.

Make sure to pick const followed by response and then await, response.json().

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we put the fetch function into a useEffect hook with an empty dependency array, it will load once the component renders.

Make sure to pick useEffect followed by useEffect and then ,, [].

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can save the loaded data in a state variable to keep track of it and later display it.

Initiate the state variable data with null and update it with the received and parsed data once available.

Make sure to pick useState followed by useState and then null, data, setData, data.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finally, we can map over the data in the return statement and render it.

Map over the data to display the name of each loaded character.

Make sure to pick data followed by .map and then person, person.name.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Convert the API response to JSON and log it in the console.

Make sure to pick data followed by await and then response, .json(), data.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why do we use await in async functions?

To pause execution until the operation is completedTo execute the next line immediatelyTo make a function synchronousTo declare a variable

To pause execution until the operation is completed.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Store the API data in state and render the names of planets.

Make sure to pick setPlanets followed by data and then planets, .map.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why do we call fetch inside the useEffect hook?

To run the code under certain conditions, such as the comments are renderedTo render the output immediately when the React app startsTo save the result in a state variableTo define the structure of the API call

To run the code under certain conditions, such as the comments are rendered.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Ensure the code waits for the fetch call to return data.

Make sure to type await.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Given the following code, what does it render?

It renders a list of planet namesIt shows an error because useEffect is missing dependenciesIt renders nothing because planets is not definedIt renders Loading... throughout

It renders a list of planet names.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render a list of Star Wars starships in the console.

Make sure to pick await followed by fetch and then data, await, response.json(), data.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent: When working on the client, we need to handle errors that might occur when trying to load data from the server.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We've already seen how to display a loading state using conditional rendering in combination with an initial falsy value, like null.

Make sure to pick null followed by data and then ?, :.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
It's good practice to handle errors. When we work with .then, we can chain a catch that executes the callback if an error is detected.

Make sure to pick .catch, followed by error.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Similar to how we store the data in a state variable, we should save the error.

Make sure to pick error followed by setError and then setError, error.message.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we have a state variable that is either null or holds the error, we can use it to extend our additional rendering.

Make sure to pick error, followed by error.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also make our own checks and throw a new error if needed. In that case, we can set the message ourselves.

Make sure to pick !response.ok, followed by throw new, and finally Error.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The error messages can be quite cryptic. For our users, we might want to display a text that's easier to understand.

Render An error occurred! instead of the real error message.

Make sure to pick An error occurred!.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
The same concept applies to working with async and await. The difference is that we wrap the asynchronous code inside a try block.

Put the code in a try block and catch the error if needed.

Make sure to pick try followed by catch and then (, error, ), setError.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Throwing our own errors works exactly the same.

Throw a new error when the response is not looking good.

Make sure to pick throw, followed by new, and finally Error.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a loading state that displays "Fetching Data..." before data is loaded.

Make sure to pick data followed by ? and then :, <p>, Fetching Data..., </p>.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Where should you add the error handling code?

In the async functionIn the useEffect hookNowhereIn the state declaration

In the async function.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use conditional rendering to display an error message "Failed to load data." if an error occurs.

Make sure to pick return, followed by return, and finally return.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
What statement correctly describes the usage of setError?

It updates the error stateIt retrieves error messages onlyIt is used to fetch dataIt sets data to null

It updates the error state.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
Demonstrate throwing a custom error if data is invalid.

Make sure to pick throw, followed by new, and finally Error.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why would you display a generic error message to users?

To make it user-friendlyTo confuse usersTo ensure users know specific error codesTo improve technical errors for developers

To make it user-friendly.

lessons.title: Lesson #16
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use try and catch within an asynchronous React function.

Make sure to pick try followed by { and then }, catch, (err), {, }.
